{{refimprove|date=February 2016}}
[[File:Sedgeford portrait.jpg|thumbnail|The "Sedgeford Hall Portrait," oil on canvas by unknown artist circa 1830; courtesy of Borough Council of King’s Lynn and West Norfolk, UK]]
The "'''Sedgeford Hall Portrait'''" (location: [[King's Lynn]] Town Hall, Norfolk, UK), is an oil on canvas portrait in the American School<ref>Pitcher, David. Borough Council of King's Lynn and West Norfolk</ref> by an unknown artist circa 1830. It depicts Pe-o-ka, wife of the [[Seminole]] chief, [[Osceola]], and their son.<ref>PalmCoastObserver.com, March 31, 2011. https://www.palmcoastobserver.com/article/palm-coast-author-solves-160-year-pocahontas-mystery</ref> It was once believed by many to be a portrait painted from life of [[Pocahontas]] and her son, [[Thomas Rolfe]].
==Provenance and identification== Eustace Neville Rolfe of [[Heacham|Heacham Hall]] in Norfolk, a possible<ref>''The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography.'' Vol. 21, No. 2 (Apr., 1913), pp. 208-211</ref> distant relative of Thomas, acquired the painting, believing it to be of Pocahontas and Thomas.<ref>Pitcher, David. Borough Council of King's Lynn and West Norfolk</ref> At some point it was hung in a Rolfe family estate building called [[Sedgeford|Sedgeford Hall]] (Norfolk, England), from whence it acquired its name. Art experts later disputed the painting's origin, saying it could not have been painted during the lifetime of Pocahontas.<ref>Friends of King's Lynn Museum Newsletter Spring 2011. http://www.oldkingsroad.com/king's%20lynn/King's%20Lynn%202011.pdf</ref> Additionally, the child in the portrait appears to be several years older than Thomas Rolfe would have been when his mother was still alive. [[Thomas Rolfe]] was born in January 1615, making him two years, two months old at the time of Pocahontas's death.
In 2010, researcher Bill Ryan, while reviewing magazine archives on the Seminole Indians, found a black-and-white drawn version of the painting in the 1848 edition of ''Illustrated London News'' identifying the portrait as "the wife and child of Osceola, the last of the Seminole Indian chiefs."<ref>PalmCoastObserver.com, March 31, 2011. https://www.palmcoastobserver.com/article/palm-coast-author-solves-160-year-pocahontas-mystery</ref> [[Osceola]] himself was of mixed race ([[Muscogee|Creek]] Indian and English), which explains the European features of the child. The portrait is now generally accepted as being his wife and son, though some questions still remain.<ref>Friends of King's Lynn Museum Newsletter Spring 2011. http://www.oldkingsroad.com/king's%20lynn/King's%20Lynn%202011.pdf</ref><ref>Pitcher, David. Borough Council of King's Lynn and West Norfolk</ref> Many printed and Internet sources, however, still refer to this painting as a portrait of Pocahontas and Thomas Rolfe.
[[File:The Wife and Child of Oscela from Holden's Dollar Magazine 1850.jpg|thumb|right|"The Wife and Child of Osceola" from ''Holden's Dollar Magazine'', volume 6, no. 4 (October 1850): 591-592.]]
An article from ''Holden's Dollar Magazine'' in 1850 labels the engraving "The Wife and Child of Osceola" and bemoans the loss of the continent's native peoples.<ref>{{cite journal | title = The Wife and Child of Osceola | journal = Holden's Dollar Magazine | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = 591–592 | publisher = | location = | date = October 1850 | url = https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/011827740 | access-date = 2016-10-07}}</ref>
A plaque,<ref>Pitcher, David. Borough Council of King's Lynn and West Norfolk</ref> presumably composed by the Rolfe family, is attached to the frame stating:
<poem> PRINCESS POCAHONTAS Dau. of PRINCE POWHATTAN & 2nd WIFE of JOHN ROLFE of HEACHAM (1585-1630) b. 1595 m.1614 d. AT GRAVESEND 1617 </poem>
The plaque contains some questionable information besides the likely misidentification of the subjects. Pocahontas was said to be a "princess" by members of the Virginia Company who marketed her as such to investors and to the royal family during her trip to England in 1616-1617.<ref>Rountree, H. C. (2005) ''Pocahontas, Powhatan, Opechancanough: Three Indian Lives Changed by Jamestown,'' University of Virginia Press, p. 176-178</ref> While she was the daughter of paramount chief, Powhatan, she was not in a matrilineal line to succeed him, and the Powhatan Indians are not known to have given her any special title corresponding to the English notion of princess, though she was likely treated with respect as the daughter of Powhatan.<ref>Rountree, H. C. (2005) ''Pocahontas, Powhatan, Opechancanough: Three Indian Lives Changed by Jamestown,'' University of Virginia Press, p. 24; p. 143</ref> Further, John Rolfe is often said to be John Rolfe of Heacham, but this has been questioned.<ref>''The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography.'' Vol. 21, No. 2 (Apr., 1913), pp. 208-211</ref> Finally, the stated birth year of 1595 is an estimate. Anthropologist and Powhatan Indian researcher Helen Rountree estimates her birth year to have been 1596 based on Pocahontas's statement of how old she was at the time of the Simon [[Van de Passe family|van de Passe]] engraving.<ref>Rountree, H. C. (2005) ''Pocahontas, Powhatan, Opechancanough: Three Indian Lives Changed by Jamestown,'' University of Virginia Press, p. 36</ref>
A sign posted under the painting at King's Lynn Town Hall gives some brief biographical details of the life of Pocahontas as well as this paragraph explaining the mis-identification of the painting's subjects: * "The mother and child portrayed are probably Pe-o-ka, the wife of Osceola, the War Chief of the Seminoles of Florida, and their child in 1837. It was acquired by Eustace Neville Rolfe of Heacham Hall who believed it represented Pocahontas and her son."<ref>King's Lynn Civic Society, King's Lynn Town Hall</ref>
'''Additional details''' * "[The Sedgeford Hall Portrait] was purchased by Eustace Neville Rolfe (1845–1908) of Heacham Hall from a Mrs Charlton who stated that ‘her husband had bought it in America years ago'."<ref>Pitcher, David. Borough Council of King's Lynn and West Norfolk</ref> * "A founder member of the King’s Lynn Town Guides, Mrs Jill Price, and her husband, encouraged the Rolfe family to hang the painting in the [King's Lynn] Town Hall. It was presented and hung in 1990."<ref>Pitcher, David. Borough Council of King's Lynn and West Norfolk</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.palmcoastobserver.com/article/palm-coast-author-solves-160-year-pocahontas-mystery “Palm Coast author solves 160-year ‘Pocahontas’ mystery”] PalmCoastObserver.com, March 31, 2011 * [http://www.oldkingsroad.com/king's%20lynn/King's%20Lynn%202011.pdf "Mystery of the King's Lynn 'Pocahontas' Painting is Solved"] from Friends of King's Lynn Museum Newsletter Spring 2011
[[Category:Native Americans in art]]

{{Portal|Ancient Near East}} The '''Sfire''' or '''Sefire steles''' are three 8th-century BCE basalt ''[[stelae]]'' containing [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] inscriptions discovered at [[Al-Safirah]] ("Sfire") near [[Aleppo]], [[Syria]].{{cite web|title=Aramaic |publisher=Anchor Bible Dictionary |pages=173–78 |author=S. A. Kaufman |url=http://www.nelc.ucla.edu/Faculty/Schniedewind_files/NWSemitic/Aramaic_ABD.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051104215025/http://www.nelc.ucla.edu/Faculty/Schniedewind_files/NWSemitic/Aramaic_ABD.pdf |archivedate=November 4, 2005 }} The '''Sefire treaty inscriptions''' are the three inscriptions on the steles.Joseph A. Fitzmyer The Aramaic inscriptions of Sefîre 1967 == Identification of the treaty kings == Two treaties conducted between minor kings from the Kingdom of [[Arpad (Syria)|Arpad]] inscribed on the stelae are often cited as evidence of the [[Aramaean]] tradition of treaty-making.{{cite web|title=''Ancient Aramaic Culture and the Bible'' |author=John F. Healy |publisher=[[University of Durham]] |date=13 June 1987 |accessdate=2007-10-12 |url=http://www.urhoy.info/culture.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828012607/http://www.urhoy.info/culture.pdf |archivedate=August 28, 2008 }} The Sefire inscriptions are of interest to those studying beliefs and practices in ancient [[Syria]] and [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] and the text is considered notable for constituting "the best extrabiblical source for [[Semitic people|West Semitic]] traditions of covenantal blessings and curses." They tell of ''"The treaty of King Bar-ga'yah of K[a]t[a]k, with Mati'el son of Attarsamak, king of Arpad."'' Some have identified this as the treaty of "Ashurnerari V" ([[Adad-nirari III]] or his son [[Tiglath-pileser III]]?) of Assyria and [[Matiilu]] (unknown) of [[Arpad (Syria)|Arpad]] (probably modern [[Tel Rifaat]], Syria).Steven Elliott Grosby ''Biblical ideas of nationality: ancient and modern'' 2002 p126 "Thus, they think that the Sefire treaty is the Aramaic version of the treaty of approximately 754 bc between Ashurnerari V and Matîoil of Arpad. But why the use of KTK as a pseudonym for Assyria? If, in fact, Dupont-Sommer's (1958) ..." == Description of the inscriptions == === Sefire I === This is a basalt slab broken in two horizontally. The first two steles each have three faces bearing writing. === Sefire II === As with Sefire I stele Sefire II had three faces bearing writing. While most of the text of Sefire II A and B permit coherent translation only with comparison with Sefire I and III, the concluding portion of Sefire II A and B is quite clear.James Bennett Pritchard The ancient Near East: supplementary texts and pictures 1969 "In Sfire II A 9, lions seem to be mentioned in the same context, offering a good parallel to ... (Sfire II C) (While most of the preserved text of Sfire II A and B permits a coherent translation only where the missing links can be supplied on the basis of Sfire I and III, the concluding portion is quite clear.Holger Gzella, M. L. Folmer Aramaic in its historical and linguistic setting 2008 p153 "personal names: Sfire II, C, 14; place names: Zkr B:10, 11 and perhaps B 4; Sfire II, C, 5; "M. L. Folmer The Aramaic language in the [[Achaemenid period]] 1995 p427 "6,8 In combination with the infinitive (hbzthm Sfire ii B 7)" ===Sefire III=== Nine fragments of the reverse of a broad slab. ==Overview== The inscriptions record two treaties that "list curses and magical rites which take effect if the treaty is violated."{{cite book|title=Magic and Divination in Ancient Palestine and Syria|author=Ann Jeffers|year=1996|publisher=BRILL|page=18|isbn=90-04-10513-1 }} One is a treaty between two minor kings, Barga'yah and Matti'el, who hailed from the southwestern periphery of the [[Assyrian empire]].{{cite journal|title=Molten Wax, Spilt Wine and Mutilated Animals: Sympathetic Magic in near Eastern and Early Greek Oath Ceremonies|author=Christopher A. Faraone|journal=The Journal of Hellenic Studies|volume= 113|year=1993|pages=60–80|accessdate=2007-10-12|url=http://www.wac.ucla.edu/pdf/greekoathceremonies.pdf|doi=10.2307/632398|format= – [https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=intitle%3A%22Molten+Wax%2C+Spilt+Wine+and+Mutilated+Animals%3A+Sympathetic+Magic+in+near+Eastern+and+Early+Greek+Oath+Ceremonies%22&as_publication=%27%27The+Journal+of+Hellenic+Studies%27%27&as_ylo=1993&as_yhi=1993&btnG=Search Scholar search]|jstor=632398|publisher=The Society for the Promotion of Hellenic Studies}} {{Dead link|date=April 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In the text, Matti'el swears to accept dire consequences for himself and his cities should he violate the stipulations of the treaty:
'''"....'''
'''As this wax is consumed by fire, thus Ma[tti'el] shall be consumed b[y fi]re.'''
'''As this bow and these arrows are broken, thus Inurta and [[Hadad]] (= names of local deities) shall break [the bow of Matti'el] and the bows of his nobles.'''
'''As a man of wax is blinded, thus Matti'el shall be blinded.'''
'''[As] this calf is cut up, thus Matti'el and his nobles shall be cut up."'''
This loyalty oath from the Sefire inscriptions is similar to other loyalty oaths imposed by Assyrian kings on other less powerful monarchs in the [[Levant]] throughout the 8th and 7th centuries BCE. The inscriptions may, under one possible interpretation, record the names of ''[[El (deity)|El]] and [[Elyon]],'' "God, God Most High" possibly providing prima facie evidence for a distinction between the two deities first worshipped by the [[Jebusites]] in [[Jerusalem]], and then elsewhere throughout the ancient Levant.{{cite book|title=Yahweh and the Gods and Goddesses of Canaan|author=John Day|publisher=Continuum International|year=2000|page=20|isbn=0-8264-6830-6}} Thought to be reflective of Assyrian or neo-Assyrian culture and similar to other documents dating from the first millennium BCE, scholars such as [[Joseph Fitzmyer]] have perceived [[Canaan]]ite influences in the text, while Dennis McCarthy has noted similarities to second millennium BCE treaties imposed by [[Hittites|Hittite]] kings on Syrian vassals.{{cite journal|title=The Sefire Treaty Stipulations and the Mesopotamian Treaty Tradition|journal=The World of the Aramaeans|author=William Morrow|editor=Paul-Eugène Dion|year=2001|publisher=Continuum International|isbn=1-84127-179-9|pages=83–84|display-editors=etal}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== Fitzmyer, Joseph A., ''The Aramaic inscriptions of Sefîre'', Biblica et orientalia Sacra Scriptura antiquitatibus orientalibus illustrata, 19; Revised edition; Rome: Pontificial Biblical Institute, 1995. Greenfield, Jonas C., "Three Notes on the Sefire Inscription," ''JSS'' 11 (1966), 98-105. [[Category:8th-century BC steles]] [[Category:Ancient Near East steles]] [[Category:Aramaic texts]] [[Category:Victory steles]] [[Category:Archaeological artifacts]] [[Category:Ancient Near East]] [[Category:Inscriptions]] [[Category:Aramaic inscriptions]] [[Category:Aleppo Governorate]] [[Category:Archaeological discoveries in Syria]]

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=July 2013}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox character | name = Sheldon Lee Cooper | series = [[The Big Bang Theory]] / [[Young Sheldon]] | image = Sheldon and Young Sheldon.jpg | caption = [[Jim Parsons]] as adult Sheldon Cooper (left) and [[Iain Armitage]] as young Sheldon Cooper (right) | first = {{Plainlist| * '''''[[The Big Bang Theory]]''''': * "[[Pilot (The Big Bang Theory)|Pilot]]" (2007) * '''''[[Young Sheldon]]''''': * "[[Young Sheldon#Episodes|Pilot]]" (2017) }} | creator = [[Chuck Lorre]]
[[Bill Prady]] | portrayer = [[Jim Parsons]] (in ''The Big Bang Theory'', voice in ''Young Sheldon'')
[[Iain Armitage]] (in ''Young Sheldon''){{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_bang_theory/news/1006793/cbs-announces-young-sheldon-a-hilarious-spinoff-of-the-big-bang-theory/|title=Get Ready To Meet Young Sheldon, A Hilarious New Spinoff Of The Big Bang Theory - CBS.com|publisher=}} | spouse = [[List of The Big Bang Theory characters#Amy|Amy Farrah Fowler]] | occupation = {{Plainlist| * '''''The Big Bang Theory''''': * [[Theoretical physicist]] * '''''Young Sheldon''''': * [[Student]] }} | fullname = Sheldon Lee Cooper | title = Doctor | family = [[List of The Big Bang Theory characters#Mary Cooper|Mary Cooper]] (mother)
George Cooper, Sr. (father)
[[List of The Big Bang Theory characters#Missy Cooper|Missy Cooper]] (twin sister)
George "Georgie" Cooper, Jr. (brother)
Missy's unnamed son (nephew)
Constance "Meemaw" Tucker''[[Young Sheldon]]'' episode "Jiu-Jitsu, Bubble Wrap, and Yoo-Hoo" (maternal grandmother)
"Pop Pop" (maternal grandfather) | gender = Male | nationality = American | religion = {{Plainlist| * "Mathology" (his invention) * Atheism }} }} '''Sheldon Lee Cooper''',{{cite episode|title=The Jerusalem Duality|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 1)#ep12|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=April 14, 2008|season=1|number=12|minutes=}} [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]], [[Doctor of Science|Sc.D.]], is a fictional character in the [[CBS]] television series ''[[The Big Bang Theory]]'' and its spinoff series ''[[Young Sheldon]]'', portrayed by actors [[Jim Parsons]] in ''The Big Bang Theory'' and [[Iain Armitage]] in ''Young Sheldon'' (with Parsons as the latter series' narrator).{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/the-big-bang-theory-sheldon-spinoff-iain-armitage-zoe-perry-cast-1202034391/|title='Big Bang' Sheldon Spinoff Inches Closer With Iain Armitage & Zoe Perry Castings|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 2, 2017|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} For his portrayal, Parsons has won four [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s, a [[Golden Globe Award]], a [[TCA Awards|TCA Award]], and two [[Critics' Choice Television Award]]s. The character's childhood is the focus of ''Young Sheldon''; the series' first season is set in 1989 when 9-year-old prodigy Sheldon has skipped ahead five grades, to start high school alongside his older brother. Sheldon is a senior [[Theoretical physics|theoretical physicist]] at [[Caltech]] and for the first ten seasons of ''The Big Bang Theory'', shares an apartment with his colleague and best friend, [[Leonard Hofstadter]] ([[Johnny Galecki]]). In season 10, Sheldon moves across the hall with his girlfriend [[List of The Big Bang Theory characters#Amy|Amy]], in the former apartment of Leonard's wife [[Penny (The Big Bang Theory)|Penny]].{{cite episode|title=The Veracity Elasticity|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 10)#ep7|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 17, 2016|season=10|number=7}} He is a former [[child prodigy]] with genius-level IQ, but displays an almost total lack of [[social skills]], a tenuous understanding of humor, and difficulty recognizing [[irony]] and [[sarcasm]] in other people, although he himself often employs them. He exhibits highly idiosyncratic behavior and a general lack of [[humility]] or [[empathy]]. He also lacks [[toleration]]. These characteristics provide the majority of the humor involving him, which has caused him to be described as the show's [[breakout character]].{{cite web|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/876/876616p1.html|title=The Big Bang Theory: Season 1 Review|work=[[IGN]]|date=May 27, 2007|accessdate=January 13, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-01-11/entertainment/1001100121_1_big-bang-theory-audience-nerds|title=Oak Park native finally gets the girl in 'Big Bang'|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=January 11, 2010|accessdate=January 13, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/the-griffin-equivalency,13255/|title=The Griffin Equivalency|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=October 13, 2008|accessdate=October 6, 2011}} Some viewers have asserted that Sheldon's personality is consistent with [[Asperger syndrome]], [[obsessive–compulsive disorder]], and [[asexuality]].{{cite web|last=Waldman|first=Allison|url=http://www.aoltv.com/2009/08/14/come-up-with-a-new-theory-sheldon-does-not-have-aspergers|title=Come up with a new theory: Sheldon does NOT have Asperger's|date=August 14, 2009|publisher=aoltv.com|accessdate=February 5, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523181231/http://www.aoltv.com/2009/08/14/come-up-with-a-new-theory-sheldon-does-not-have-aspergers/|archivedate=May 23, 2012}} Co-creator [[Bill Prady]] has stated that Sheldon's character was neither conceived nor developed with regard to any of these traits, although Parsons has said that in his opinion, Sheldon "couldn't display ''more'' traits" of Asperger's. ==Creation and casting== The character of Sheldon Cooper was inspired by a computer programmer personally known to series co-creator Bill Prady.{{cite web|url=http://thetvaddict.com/2009/04/17/paley-festival-recap-%E2%80%9809-the-big-bang-theory/|title=Paley Festival Recap `09: The Big Bang Theory|work=theTVaddict.com|date=April 17, 2009|accessdate=January 20, 2010}} He is named in honor of actor/producer [[Sheldon Leonard]]{{cite web|url=http://weblogs.variety.com/season_pass/2009/05/big-bang-theory-we-didnt-anticipate-how-protective-the-audience-would-feel-toward-our-guys.html|title='Big Bang Theory': 'We didn't anticipate how protective the audience would feel about our guys'|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=May 5, 2009|accessdate=February 5, 2010|quote=''Q. Are Sheldon and Leonard named after the brilliant (producer) Sheldon Leonard of "The Andy Griffith Show", "The Danny Thomas Show", "The Dick Van Dyke Show", "My Favorite Martian" and "I Spy?" (Binnie)'' A. Yep. Chuck and I are both fans. Chuck's idea.}} and Nobel Prize Laureate [[Leon Cooper]].{{cite web|url=http://vos.lavoz.com.ar/content/la-formula-perfecta-del-humor-0|title=The Big Bang Theory, la fórmula perfecta del humor|publisher=}} [[Chuck Lorre]] originally intended [[Johnny Galecki]] to play the role, but Galecki thought he would be "better suited" for the character of Leonard.{{cite web|url=http://www.collider.com/entertainment/interviews/article.asp/aid/11261/tcid/1|title=Johnny Galecki Exclusive Video Interview – The Big Bang Theory|work=collider.com|date=March 15, 2009|accessdate=January 20, 2010}} Lorre said that when [[Jim Parsons]] auditioned for the role, he was "so startlingly good" that he was asked to reaudition "to make sure he hadn't gotten lucky".{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/arts/tv/features/59213/|title=The Science Guy|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|author=Emma Rosenblum|date=September 20, 2009|accessdate=January 20, 2010}} Sheldon is one of four characters to appear in every episode of the series, along with Leonard, Howard, and Raj. ==Characterization== ===Early life=== Sheldon was raised in [[Galveston, Texas]]{{cite episode|title=The White Asparagus Triangulation|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 2)#ep26|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=November 24, 2008|season=2|number=9|minutes=04:15}} along with his elder brother, George Jr., and [[Twin|fraternal twin]] sister, Missy, by his mother, Mary Cooper, an overtly devout Baptist; and George Cooper, an alcoholic who was rarely around.{{Cite news|url=https://mondaymondaynetwork.com/entertainment/the-family-dynasty-part-1-sheldon-coopers-family/|title=The Family Dynasty - Part 1: Sheldon Cooper’s Family|date=2016-11-16|work=MondayMondayNetwork.com|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}} Sheldon once got his father fired when he told Mr. Hinckley, a store owner, that George was stealing from the cash register.{{cite episode|title=The Sales Call Sublimation|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 9)#ep12|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=January 7, 2015|season=9|number=12}} In ''Young Sheldon'', this is [[retcon]]ned: his father is a football coach who was fired from his coaching position in Galveston because he disclosed that other coaches were illegally recruiting players to their school, forcing the family to return to Medford. He does drink, mostly beer, but is a loving father who is trying to understand his intellectually gifted son. The only member of his family to have actively encouraged his work in science was his grandfather, whom he cherished and affectionately called "Pop-Pop", and who died when Sheldon was five years old. Pop-Pop's loss is what caused Sheldon to despise Christmas when his Christmas wish to bring Pop-Pop back didn't come true. Sheldon's closest relative is his maternal grandmother whom he affectionately calls "Meemaw", and who in turn calls him "Moon Pie".{{Cite news|url=https://mondaymondaynetwork.com/entertainment/family-dynasty-part-2-sheldon-coopers-family/|title=The Family Dynasty Part 2: Sheldon Cooper’s Family|date=2016-11-16|work=MondayMondayNetwork.com|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}} His aunt also encouraged Sheldon by giving him medical equipment, "in case his work in physics failed, he'd have a 'trade' to fall back on". Sheldon was interested in science from an early age, and was a [[child prodigy]],{{cite episode|title=The Creepy Candy Coating Corollary|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 3)#ep45|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 19, 2009|season=3|number=5}} although due to his behavioral quirks and his lack of humility about his superior intellect, he was bullied by classmates and neighbors. Sheldon entered college at the age of eleven,{{cite episode|title=The Hamburger Postulate|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 1)#ep5|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 22, 2007|season=1|number=5}} and at age fourteen he graduated from college ''[[Latin honors|summa cum laude]]''.{{cite episode|title=The Pants Alternative|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 3)#ep18|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=March 22, 2010|season=3|number=18}} (To this day, the college he went to for undergraduate studies has yet to be revealed, but he feels it is superior to his fellow ''Big Bang Theory'' colleagues' alma maters of Princeton (Leonard), MIT (Howard) and Harvard (Amy) - however, it is implied in "The Tam Turbulence" that Sheldon is a Caltech alumnus.) From then, he worked on his doctorate, was a visiting professor at the [[University of Heidelberg]] in Germany, was the youngest person at the time to receive the Stevenson Award, and has appeared on the cover of ''[[Journal of Physical Chemistry A]]''.{{cite episode|title=The Emotion Detection Automation|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 10)#ep14|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=February 7, 2017|season=10|number=14}} Sheldon is now a theoretical physicist doing research at [[Caltech]], although he stated in ''[[Young Sheldon]]'' that he couldn't see himself living in California due to their carefree lifestyle. ===Personality=== {{Redirect|Bazinga|the jellyfish genus|Bazinga (genus)}} Sheldon is often described as a stereotypical "geek". He is usually characterized as being extremely intelligent, detail-oriented, eccentric, and occasionally disturbing. Despite his intelligence, he often displays childlike qualities, such as extreme stubbornness and a lack of [[common sense]]. It is claimed by Bernadette that the reason Sheldon is sometimes unpleasant is because the part of his brain that tells him it is wrong to be nasty is "getting a wedgie from the rest of his brain", although, in season 8's "The Space Probe Disintegration",{{Cite news|url=https://mondaymondaynetwork.com/entertainment/big-bang-theory-sheldon-bloopers/|title=The Big Bang Theory Sheldon Bloopers|date=2018-01-28|work=MondayMondayNetwork.com|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}} Sheldon tearfully admits to Leonard that he ''is'' aware of his peculiarities and how his behavior comes across. The first four episodes of ''The Big Bang Theory'' portray Sheldon slightly inconsistently with respect to his later characterization, in which he is depicted as rather witty and sarcastic, and slightly flirtatious towards Penny in the pilot episode: according to Prady, the character "began to evolve after episode five or so and became his own thing".{{cite web|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2009/08/14/come-up-with-a-new-theory-sheldon-does-not-have-aspergers|title=Come up with a new theory: Sheldon does NOT have Asperger's |publisher=[[TV Squad]]|date=August 14, 2009|accessdate=October 6, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817125113/http://www.tvsquad.com/2009/08/14/come-up-with-a-new-theory-sheldon-does-not-have-aspergers|archivedate=August 17, 2009}} Sheldon possesses an [[eidetic memory]] and an IQ of 187,{{cite episode|title=The Pancake Batter Anomaly|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 1)#ep11|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=March 31, 2008|season=1|number=11|minutes=09:58|quote=Penny, I have an IQ of 187}} although he claims his IQ cannot be accurately measured by normal tests.{{cite episode|title=The Codpiece Topology|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 2)#ep19|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=September 29, 2008|season=2|number=2|minutes=08:20}} He originally claimed to have a master's degree and two [[Doctorate|doctoral degrees]], but this list has increased.{{cite episode|title=The Big Bran Hypothesis|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 1)#ep2|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 1, 2007|season=1|number=2|minutes=16:00}}{{cite episode|title=The Robotic Manipulation|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 4)#ep64|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=September 23, 2010|season=4|number=1|minutes=09:36}} Sheldon has an extensive general knowledge in many subjects including [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[biology]], [[astronomy]], [[cosmology]], [[algebra]], [[calculus]], [[economics]], [[Computer|computers]], [[vexillology]], [[engineering]], [[history]], [[geography]], [[linguistics]], [[football]], [[Train|trains]], ''[[Star Trek]]'' and in addition to being fluent in [[Klingon language|Klingon]], has some knowledge of [[Finnish language|Finnish]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]] and [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]].{{cite episode|title=The Creepy Candy Coating Corollary|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 3)#ep5|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 19, 2009|season=3|number=5|minutes=13:55}} He also shows great talent in music, knowing how to play the [[piano]] (as does Parsons in real life), the [[bongos]], the [[Recorder (musical instrument)|recorder]], [[theremin]] (which Parsons learned to play in real life), showing some skill in [[Tuvan throat singing]] and also having [[perfect pitch]].{{cite episode|title=The Bon Voyage Reaction|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 6)#ep24|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=May 16, 2013|season=6|number=24}} Although his friends have similar intellects to him, his eccentricities, stubbornness, and lack of empathy often frustrate them. Sheldon occasionally uses slang (in a very unnatural fashion), and follows jokes with his [[catchphrase]] "Bazinga!" which is now an officially registered trademark of [[Warner Bros.]]{{cite web|title=Bazinga! |author=Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc. |url=http://www.trademarkia.com/bazinga-85210353.html |accessdate=September 24, 2011}}{{cite web|title=USPTO Trademark Status and Document Retrieval|url=http://tsdr.uspto.gov/#caseNumber=85210239&caseType=SERIAL_NO&searchType=statusSearch|accessdate=February 18, 2013}} He is uncomfortable with human physical contact and has [[Mysophobia|germophobia]], which makes his exceptionally rare hugs extremely awkward and painful-looking. He also has [[hemophobia]].''[[The Big Bang Theory (season 5)|s5 e16, The Vacation Solution]] Sheldon has difficulty coping when asked to keep a secret, when he is interrupted, or when he hears arguing.{{cite episode|title=The Bad Fish Paradigm|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=September 22, 2008|season=2|number=1}}{{cite episode|title=The Friendship Algorithm|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=January 19, 2009|season=2|number=13}}{{cite episode|title=The Guitarist Amplification|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=November 9, 2009|season=3|number=7}} He is also a [[notary public]] and uses his knowledge in law and contracts usually for his own advantage and is always distressed when challenged in a legal aspect that he cannot logically defend. In his mannerisms, Sheldon also shows symptoms associated with [[obsessive-compulsive personality disorder]]. Whenever approaching a person's home, he must knock three times, then say the person's name, and must repeat this at least three times (where "The first one is traditional, but two and three are for people to get their pants on"), as a result of him walking in on his father with another woman when he was thirteen.{{cite episode|title=The Hot Tub Contamination|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 16, 2016|season=10|number=5}} Upon entering a person's home, he must select the proper seat before sitting down. When it is suggested by Penny that he "just sit anywhere", his response is "Oh, no, if only it were that simple!" This extends to his inability to accept change. His rigidity in maintaining [[homeostasis]] often causes him frustration. Because of his rigidity and stubbornness, only his mother and Bernadette{{cite episode|title=[[The Big Bang Theory (season 3)#ep14|The Einstein Approximation]]|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=February 1, 2010|season=3|number=14}} – both possessing strong maternal personalities – have shown the ability to order him to do things. Like his friends, Sheldon is fond of comic books (especially the [[DC Universe]]), [[cosplay|costumes]], [[video game]]s, [[roleplaying game]]s, [[tabletop game]]s, [[collectible card game]]s, and action figures. Sheldon has [[restraining orders]] from his heroes [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Carl Sagan]], and [[Stan Lee]],{{cite episode|title=The Large Hadron Collision|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=February 8, 2010|season=3|number=15}}{{cite episode|title=The Excelsior Acquisition|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=March 1, 2010|season=3|number=16}}{{Cite episode|title=The Vacation Solution|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 5)#ep103|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=February 9, 2012|season=5|number=16|minutes=12:55}}Season 2, episode 11: The Bath Item Gift Hypothesis as well as television scientist [[Bill Nye]].{{cite episode|title=The Proton Displacement|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 7)#ep142|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=November 7, 2013|season=7|number=7|minutes=16:23}} Sheldon often wears vintage T-shirts adorned with superhero logos. One of his shirts is emblazoned with the number 73, and in the episode "The Alien Parasite Hypothesis" he explains that 73 is the 21st prime number, its mirror, 37, is the 12th prime number and its mirror (21) is the product of multiplying 7 and 3, also in binary, 73 is 1001001, a [[palindrome]]. The boys use video games like bowling and archery for "exercise" and use the traditional sport rules. Sheldon has sometimes shown empathy, including lending money to [[Penny (The Big Bang Theory)|Penny]] without expecting it back quickly (although that may just have been his logical Spock-like response to a problem to be solved; it was, after all, money he was not using and would not miss{{cite episode|title=The Financial Permeability|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=February 2, 2009|season=2|number=14}}) and driving her to a hospital when her shoulder was dislocated.{{cite episode|title=The Adhesive Duck Deficiency|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=November 16, 2009|season=3|number=9}} Since season 10, his empathy skills have improved to the extent that he goes out of his way to pamper his fiance Amy. Sheldon admits he is overly fond of koalas munching on eucalyptus so much that he has a facial expression that he refers to as his koala face."The Tiny Trinket Maneuver". ''The Big Bang Theory''.Season 5. episode 12. January 12, 2012. CBS. He dislikes gifts, because the "social contract" in his view creates either a debt or burden on the receiver of the gift which will not stop until one of the two involved in the "gift-relationship" dies leaving the other either in debt or with an undue surplus.{{cite episode|title=The Bath Item Gift Hypothesis|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=December 15, 2008|season=2|number=11}} Sheldon also does not take drugs, not even legal ones such as caffeine, due to a promise to his mother, and is hypersensitive when he accidentally consumes them.{{cite episode|title=The Work Song Nanocluster|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|season=2|number=18}} It has been shown, however, that alcohol often causes Sheldon to loosen up significantly, although it will also cloud his judgment – on occasion, after drinking alcoholic drinks (both deliberately and accidentally), he has done things that he would never do while sober, such as singing out loud,{{cite episode|title=The Grasshopper Experiment|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=November 12, 2007|season=1|number=8}} mooning an audience full of people, confronting [[Wil Wheaton]],{{cite episode|title=The Habitation Configuration|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=November 8, 2012|season=6|number=7}}, leaving wildly inappropriate voicemails after "drunk dialling" [[Stephen Hawking]], and affectionately slapping Amy's rear.{{cite episode|title=The Thanksgiving Decoupling|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=November 21, 2013|season=7|number=9}} In response to criticism from his friends that he is mentally ill, Sheldon often retorts, "I'm not crazy; my mother had me tested" – which his mother has confirmed to be true (once while wishing she had gone through with a follow-up examination).{{cite episode|title=The Cushion Saturation|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=March 2, 2009|season=2|number=16}}{{cite episode|title=The Griffin Equivalency|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 13, 2008|season=2|number=7}}{{cite episode|title=The Rhinitis Revelation|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 20, 2011|season=5|number=6}} ===Family=== Sheldon contrasts strongly with his family, who are neither scientists nor intellectuals. His father George died before the start of ''The Big Bang Theory'', when Sheldon was 14,{{cite episode|title=The Proton Transmogrification|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=May 1, 2014|season=7|number=22}} while his mother Mary is a devout born-again Christian and loving parent. Sheldon has two siblings: a twin sister, Missy, who is a tall, attractive brunette as an adult; and an older brother,{{cite episode|title=The Jiminy Conjecture|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=April 27, 2009|season=3|number=2}} George Jr., who owns a [[tire]] store chain headquartered in [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] called Dr. Tire{{cite episode|title=The Sibling Realignment|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=May 3, 2018|season=11|number=23}}. The adult Sheldon has stated that both Missy and George Jr. beat up Sheldon during their childhoods, and their mother describes them to be "dumb as soup".{{cite episode|title=The Luminous Fish Effect|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 1)#ep4|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 15, 2007|season=1|number=4}} In the pilot episode of ''The Big Bang Theory'', Sheldon tells Leonard that DNA is not a guarantee of an intelligent offspring as he himself is a theoretical physicist and his twin sister is a hostess at [[Fuddruckers]]. Sheldon is very fond of his maternal grandmother, whom he calls "Meemaw" and who calls him "[[Moon Pie]]".{{cite episode|title=The Terminator Decoupling|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=March 9, 2009|season=2|number=17}} He called his grandfather, who died when Sheldon was five, "Pop Pop".{{cite episode|title=The Santa Simulation|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 6)#ep11|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=December 13, 2012|season=6|number=11}} Sheldon was also very close to his grandfather, stating once that his grandfather is the only relative he had who encouraged him to become involved in science. Sheldon has a maternal uncle, Edward, who is called "Stumpy" as the result of a time when he cleaned a wood chipper by hand. He also has a maternal aunt, Charlene, which was revealed in ''Young Sheldon'' when his mother told Meemaw that she made dinner for “Charlene and Edward” more times than her. Sheldon had another uncle, named Carl Cooper, who was killed by a badger while cleaning a chimney and another uncle that may have done things to children that were legal in Oklahoma per "The Clean Room Infiltration". In "The Engagement Reaction", Sheldon mentions that his aunt Ruth died a week after being infected by a pathogen she contracted in the hospital where she visited Sheldon's uncle Roger, and that their ashes are now stored in a coffee can on Sheldon's mother’s mantle. In the ''Young Sheldon'' episode "Vanilla Ice Cream, Gentleman Callers, and a Dinette Set", it is revealed that Sheldon has children in the future. ===Relationships=== Sheldon's closest friends are [[Leonard Hofstadter]], [[Howard Wolowitz]], and [[Raj Koothrappali]]. Of the three, Sheldon is openly dismissive of Howard and constantly [[wikt:opine|opines]] that a master's degree in engineering demonstrates a lesser intellect than that of the others, who all possess science doctorates. Despite that, Sheldon has referred to Howard as a "treasured acquaintance"{{cite episode|title=The Bozeman Reaction|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 3)#ep13|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=January 18, 2010|season=3|number=13}} and later his friend{{cite episode|title=The Friendship Turbulence|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 7)#ep17|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=March 6, 2014|season=7|number=17}} at various points. Sheldon constantly belittles Leonard and dismisses his work, yet at the same time considers Leonard his best friend, as they used to live together and can tolerate each other: in "The Space Probe Disintegration", Sheldon admits to Leonard that he is aware of how difficult he can be, and tearfully expresses his gratitude for having Leonard in his life in spite of himself, causing Leonard to break down beside him. Prady stated that "the fact that, despite everything, Leonard considers Sheldon his best friend reminds us of Sheldon's essential humanity".{{cite web|url=http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2010/01/big-bang-theory-johnny-galecki-cbs-sheldon-leonard.html|title=Having 'Big' fun on a hit comedy: A chat with 'Big Bang Theory's' Johnny Galecki|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=January 10, 2010|accessdate=January 15, 2010}} Sheldon can only handle having a limited number of friends in his life at a time, but later shows flexibility when he accepts Bernadette and Amy as part of the social group. In season 6, the guys ask if comic book store owner Stuart can be part of the group while Howard is in space.The Decoupling Fluctuation, October 4, 2012. Despite Penny's neither being a scientist nor sharing many of the group's interests,{{cite web|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/106/1065246p2.html|title=Bazinga! Sheldon Speaks|work=[[IGN]]|date=January 29, 2010|accessdate=February 1, 2010}} and having constant fights with Sheldon in the early episodes, they become close friends.{{cite episode|title=The Pancake Batter Anomaly|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 1)#ep11|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=March 31, 2008|season=1|number=11}} While some fans support a romantic relationship between Sheldon and Penny,{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/dodgerthoughts/2009/12/big-bang-theory.html|title='The Big Bang Theory': Why Penny and Sheldon will hook up|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=Jon Weisman|date=December 8, 2009|accessdate=January 18, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213013143/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/dodgerthoughts/2009/12/big-bang-theory.html|archivedate=December 13, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://ausiellofiles.ew.com/2009/04/27/big-bang-video//|title='Big Bang' video: Jim Parsons tackles Sheldon-Penny romance, the virginity thing, and more!|work=The Ausiello Files|date=April 27, 2009|accessdate=January 13, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926160414/http://ausiellofiles.ew.com/2009/04/27/big-bang-video/|archivedate=September 26, 2009|df=mdy-all}} Lorre has stated his opposition to it by saying: "We've stumbled into creating a character who has chosen a lifestyle for himself that is unique. And I don't see any reason to modify it."{{cite web|url=http://ausiellofiles.ew.com/2010/01/09/big-bang-scoop-romance-for-penny-and-sheldon/|title=Big Bang scoop: Romance for Penny and Sheldon?|work=[[IGN]]|date=January 9, 2010|accessdate=January 13, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114034133/http://ausiellofiles.ew.com/2010/01/09/big-bang-scoop-romance-for-penny-and-sheldon/|archivedate=January 14, 2010|df=mdy-all}} It has been speculated that Sheldon may be [[Asexuality|asexual]] or [[aromantic]]. Series co-creator Chuck Lorre said: "Part of what's wonderful and unique about [Sheldon] is he has chosen not to play in the relationship game either way  – heterosexual, homosexual, bisexual, any sexuality." This is referenced in "The Cooper-Nowitzki Theorem", when Sheldon unknowingly attracts the attention of grad student Ramona Nowitzki, and Penny, seeing this, asks his friends what his "deal" (i.e., sexual orientation) is, to which Leonard responds, "Honestly, we've been operating under the assumption that he has no 'deal'." [[File:Mayim Bialik and Jim Parsons at PaleyFest 2013.jpg|thumb|right|[[Mayim Bialik]] (who portrays [[Amy Farrah Fowler]]) and Jim Parsons at PaleyFest 2013 for the TV show "Big Bang Theory"]] In the [[The Big Bang Theory (season 3)#ep63|season 3 finale]], Howard and Raj blackmail Sheldon into meeting [[Amy Farrah Fowler]], with whom they matched him on a dating website. After some obnoxious comments about the dating website, Sheldon finds that Amy agrees with him, and he grows fond of her when she says that "Any or all physical contact up to and including [[coitus]] are off the table". Their relationship continues in season 4, although Sheldon often points out that they are not in a romantic relationship. The two enjoy intellectual games they create, and Amy and Sheldon openly express the same type of intellectual superiority.{{cite episode|title=[[The Big Bang Theory (season 4)#ep3|The Zazzy Substitution]]|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 7, 2010|season=4|number=03}} In season 5, when Leonard inadvertently implies that he and Amy may have had sex after a wedding reception that they both attended, Sheldon unexpectedly reacts violently, karate-chopping Leonard's neck while telling Leonard "She is not for you... not for you!"{{cite episode|title=[[The Big Bang Theory (season 5)#ep3|The Pulled Groin Extrapolation]]|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=September 29, 2011|season=5|number=03}} Later, Sheldon formally asks Amy to be his girlfriend in "[[The Flaming Spittoon Acquisition]]". During their relationship, Amy begins a campaign to give Sheldon more attention to increase his feelings for her by embracing his interests.{{cite episode|title=[[The Big Bang Theory (season 5)#ep3|The Launch Acceleration]]|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=May 3, 2012|season=5|number=23}} As they watch Howard being launched into space in its season finale, Amy is surprised when Sheldon takes her hand for emotional support.{{cite episode|title=[[The Big Bang Theory (season 5)#ep3|The Countdown Reflection]]|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=May 10, 2012|season=5|number=24}} During the first half of season 6, in "[[The Big Bang Theory (season 6)|The Parking Spot Escalation]]" and "[[The Fish Guts Displacement]]", Sheldon is pushed further after seeing Amy partially exposed and taking care of her while she is ill respectively. In "[[The Big Bang Theory (season 6)|The Cooper/Kripke Inversion]]", after being directly asked by Penny if he would ever have sex with Amy, Sheldon admits to Penny and Leonard that a physical relationship with Amy is a possibility, and being touched is something he is working on. While upset about Kripke, Amy does give him a consoling hug that Sheldon seems to need, and want. Even so, Amy has offered other romantic physical contact, and was very uncomfortable when they had to cuddle. In "[[The Big Bang Theory (season 6)|The Spoiler Alert Segmentation]]", Leonard temporarily moves out and Amy proposes that she would be his perfect roommate and tries to move in, though Sheldon is uncomfortable with this change in their relationship. While playing Dungeons and Dragons during "[[The Big Bang Theory (season 6)|The Love Spell Potential]]", Sheldon's and Amy's characters are commanded to have sex within the game. A very upset Amy asks Sheldon if they are ever going to be intimate and he again admits that it is a possibility. In season 7, Sheldon passionately kisses Amy on the lips for the first time. Initially to prove a point, he later prolonged it, implying he enjoyed the feeling.{{cite episode|title=[[The Big Bang Theory (season 7)#ep15|The Locomotive Manipulation]]|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=February 6, 2014|season=7|number=15}} Later episodes showed him willingly kissing Amy, implying he has gotten more comfortable in such a position of physical intimacy. The ultimate proof of Sheldon having feelings for Amy is given in the season 8 episode "[[The Big Bang Theory (season 8)|The Prom Equivalency]]", when he finally admits being in love with her: "I love you too. There's no denying I have feelings for you that can't be explained in any other way. I briefly considered I had a brain parasite, but that seems even more far-fetched. The only conclusion was love." In the season 8 finale, "[[The Big Bang Theory (season 8)|The Commitment Determination]]", Sheldon and Amy get into a fight over their definition of "commitment". Sheldon feels his relationship with Amy is going fast on its own, but Amy argues he is taking things too slowly and does not properly bestow on her unlimited affection. By the episode's end she has decided to take a break from their relationship while Sheldon is left numb from Amy's revelation. He glumly reveals that he had been planning on proposing to Amy with his grandmother's ring, a family heirloom. In the season 9 premiere, Sheldon keeps pushing Amy to make up her mind about their relationship, but goes too far and insults her to her face and she angrily breaks up with him for good, thus officially ending their relationship. In "[[The Big Bang Theory (season 9)|The Platonic Permutation]]" Amy offers Sheldon to get back together with her after spending time together in an aquarium at Thanksgiving, but sadly learns that he simply just wants to be her friend, with him revealing to her that "I excel at many things, but getting over you wasn't one of them". In "[[The Big Bang Theory (season 9)|The Earworm Reverberation]]", Sheldon can't get a [[Darlin' (The Beach Boys song)|song]] out his head, but after suddenly remembering the title and the lyrics, he realizes that the song was about Amy and that she changed his life for the better, which prompts him to go to her apartment to profess his love. He finds Amy on a date with Dave, who has a great adoration for Sheldon because of his intellect. Seeing how much they love each other, Dave gleefully urges Sheldon to kiss Amy, leading to their reunion. In the following episode, "[[The Big Bang Theory (season 9)|The Opening Night Excitation]]" Leonard, Howard and Raj go to see ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]]'' without Sheldon as while he was initially reluctant, ultimately opted to celebrate Amy's birthday with her instead. To make Amy's birthday enjoyable and memorable, Sheldon seeks out Penny and Bernadette as he respects their opinions regarding all things socially appropriate. He reveals to them that he has narrowed things down to three options, the first being a chance to play the [[harp]] with the [[Los Angeles Philharmonic]], the second being an all-expense paid trip to the Wisconsin Sheep and Wool Festival (though Amy would have to go alone because Sheldon's [[ornithophobia]] is nothing compared to his ovinaphobia), and the third being the two of them engaging in [[coitus]], at which point Penny squeezes and shatters the wine glass in her hand due to disbelief and/or shock. After Penny and Bernadette convince him that finally being intimate with her is the most beautiful gift that he could give to her, Sheldon and Amy have sex for the first time on the latter's birthday. In season 10, Sheldon and Amy move in together for a five-week experiment to test out their compatibility,{{cite episode|title=The Cohabitation Experimentation|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 10)#ep4|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 10, 2016|season=10|number=4}} and after its successful run, decide to move in together permanently. In its season finale, Sheldon unexpectedly proposes to Amy after being hit on by Ramona Nowitzki. In the eleventh season premiere, Amy accepts his proposal, and they marry in the season finale.{{Cite news|url=https://mondaymondaynetwork.com/entertainment/the-big-bang-theory/these-behind-the-scenes-big-bang-theory-wedding-details-will-shock-you/|title=These Behind The Scenes Big Bang Theory Details Will SHOCK You|last=|first=|date=2018-05-28|work=MondayMondayNetwork.com|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}} He once idolized fictional prodigy [[Wesley Crusher]] from ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'', portrayed by Wil Wheaton, until Wheaton did not show up at a convention attended by Sheldon in 1995. Sheldon had spent 15 hours on a bus travelling to the convention during which time he was forced to break his rule about urinating in a moving vehicle. After this moment Wil Wheaton became number six on Sheldon's mortal enemy list (a list he started when he was 9 on a 5¼-inch [[floppy disk]]). Wheaton was one of Sheldon's mortal enemies, along with his coworkers [[Barry Kripke]] and [[Leslie Winkle]]. Later, Wheaton managed to patch things up with Sheldon, only to inadvertently pass the enemy list spot to [[Brent Spiner]].{{cite episode|title=The Russian Rocket Reaction|episodelink=The Big Bang Theory (season 5)#ep5|series=The Big Bang Theory|serieslink=The Big Bang Theory|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 13, 2011|season=5|number=5|minutes=}} Sheldon would later resume his enmity with Wheaton in season 11's "The Proton Regeneration" when they compete for the lead role in an Internet reboot of Sheldon's childhood favorite science TV series, ''Professor Proton'', and Wheaton gets the part: however, when he sees how well Wheaton plays the role and on the advice of Howard, he apologizes to him. ==Reception and legacy== ===General=== [[File:Двухслойный трафарет.jpg|thumb|Sheldon Cooper doing the [[Vulcan salute]], stencil graffiti on a wall in [[Volgograd]], Russia]] Parsons' portrayal of Sheldon has received widespread acclaim, and is often cited as the main reason for the program's success by critics and fans alike.{{cite news|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/entertainment/the_tab/the_buzz-39481582.html|title=The buzz: Jim Parsons as Sheldon|last=Oswald|first=Brad|work=[[Winnipeg Free Press]]|accessdate=January 13, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100313081930/http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/entertainment/the_tab/the_buzz-39481582.html|archivedate=March 13, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/Entertainment/Television/article/575764|title=Nerd herd doing a bang-up job|last=Salem|first=Rob|date=January 24, 2009|work=The Toronto Star|accessdate=January 13, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/tv/articles/2009/02/08/gentle_twists_on_reliable_formulas_keep_viewers_hooked/|title=Gentle twists on reliable formulas keep viewers hooked|last=Gilbert|first=Matthew|date=February 8, 2009|work=The Boston Globe|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} James Chamberlin of IGN wrote: "It's hard to imagine what ''The Big Bang Theory'' would be if it weren't for Jim Parsons' great portrayal of Sheldon Cooper".{{cite web|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/946/946275p1.html|title="The Friendship Algorithm" Review|work=[[IGN]]|date=January 20, 2009|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} Matt Roush of ''[[TV Guide]]'' stated that "there's a spark of divine inspiration in Jim Parsons' uproarious Sheldon Cooper".{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguidemagazine.com/matt-roush-daily-review/what-a-year-3521.html|title=What a Year!|work=[[TV Guide]]|date=December 14, 2009|accessdate=January 13, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100218155304/http://www.tvguidemagazine.com/matt-roush-daily-review/what-a-year-3521.html|archivedate=February 18, 2010}} Ken Tucker of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' wrote that: "Parsons is doing something rare on network TV: making intellectualism admirable, even heroic".{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20237937,00.html|title=The Big Bang Theory|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=November 5, 2008|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} On July 16, 2009, Parsons was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series]].{{cite web|url=http://cdn.emmys.tv/awards/2009ptemmys/61stemmys_noms.php |title=61st Primetime Emmy® Awards | Academy of Television Arts & Sciences |publisher=Cdn.emmys.tv |date=July 19, 2012 |accessdate=July 27, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091106152818/http://cdn.emmys.tv/awards/2009ptemmys/61stemmys_nomswin_pt.php?action=search_db#1|archivedate=November 6, 2009}} He was nominated again for the same award on July 8, 2010, and eventually won the award on August 29, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/sites/emmys.com/files/62ndemmys_noms.pdf|title=Complete Emmy listings|accessdate=July 8, 2010|format=PDF|publisher=Emmy Award|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215131620/http://www.emmys.com/sites/emmys.com/files/62ndemmys_noms.pdf|archive-date=December 15, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} On August 1, 2009, he won the [[TCA Award for Individual Achievement in Comedy]], with the show itself winning the award for [[TCA Award for Outstanding Achievement in Comedy|Outstanding Achievement in Comedy]] for season 2.{{cite web|url=http://goldderby.latimes.com/awards_goldderby/2009/08/tca-awards-television-critics-association-news-.html|title=TCA Awards hail 'True Blood' and (finally) 'Battlestar Galactica'|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=August 2, 2009|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} He was nominated again for the same award in 2010 and 2012. Parsons was also nominated for the [[People's Choice Award]] for Favorite TV Comedy Actor{{cite web|url=http://www.peopleschoice.com/pca/awards/nominees/index.jsp|title=People's Choice Awards Nominees & Winners:2010|publisher=peoplschoice.com|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} and a [[Satellite Award for Best Actor – Television Series Musical or Comedy]] in 2009, 2010, and 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.pressacademy.com/satawards/awards2009.shtml|title=2009 14th Annual Satellite Awards|publisher=pressacademy.com|accessdate=January 13, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008032601/http://www.pressacademy.com/satawards/awards2009.shtml|archivedate=October 8, 2011}} On January 16, 2011, Parsons won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television Series Musical or Comedy]], presented by co-star [[Kaley Cuoco]], for his work on seasons 3 and 4. On June 20, 2011, he won the [[Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Actor in a Comedy Series]] at the [[1st Critics' Choice Television Awards]] for his work on season 4, and was nominated again for the same award in 2012. On September 18, 2011, he won his second consecutive [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Primetime Emmy Award - Lead Actor in Comedy]], and was nominated again for the same award on July 19, 2012. In 2013, Parsons was nominated once again for the Golden Globe and received his first nomination for the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Comedy Series]]. In 2013 & 2014, Parsons was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Primetime Emmy Award - Lead Actor in Comedy]] for the 5th and 6th time, respectively, both of which he won for his 3rd and 4th [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Primetime Emmy Awards - Lead Actor in a Comedy Series]] meaning that Parsons had won this award 4 times in the last 5 years, including back-to-back in 2010/2011and 2013/2014. No actor, in the history of this award has won back-to-back awards on two separate occasions, and his total of 4 awards puts Parsons in a four-way tie at the top with comedy legends [[Carroll O'Connor]], [[Kelsey Grammer]], and [[Michael J. Fox]]. The asteroid [[List of minor planets: 246001–247000#246201–246300|246247 Sheldoncooper]] was named after Sheldon.{{cite web|url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=246247;orb=0;cov=0;log=0;cad=0#discovery|title=JPL Small-Body Database|accessdate=September 1, 2012}} In 2012, a newly discovered species of bee was named ''[[Euglossa bazinga]]'', after the character's noted [[catch phrase]], "Bazinga!"{{cite news |url=http://blogs.smithsonianmag.com/smartnews/2012/12/a-brand-new-bee-was-just-named-after-sheldon-from-the-big-bang-theory |title=A Brand New Bee Was Just Named After Sheldon From 'The Big Bang Theory' |first=Rose |last=Eveleth |date=December 17, 2012 |publisher=Smithsonion.com |agency=Smart News |accessdate=May 21, 2013}} In March 2013, the [[Columbus Zoo and Aquarium]] named a [[black-and-white colobus]] after Sheldon.{{cite news|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Zoo-names-monkey-after-TV-character/tabid/418/articleID/295533/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Zoo names monkey after TV character| date=April 25, 2013}} In 2015, a new echinocaridid phyllocaridan from the Lower Devonian of central-eastern Poland, was named ''Ptychocaris sheldoni'' after Sheldon.{{Cite journal|last=Mazurek|first=Dawid|last2=Dec|first2=Marek|last3=Łukowiak|first3=Magdalena|date=2015-11-01|title=A New Echinocaridid Phyllocaridan from the Lower Devonian of Central-Eastern Poland|url=https://academic.oup.com/jcb/article/35/6/785/2547877|journal=Journal of Crustacean Biology|volume=35|issue=6|pages=785–788|doi=10.1163/1937240x-00002384|issn=0278-0372}} ===Asperger syndrome=== Some viewers have asserted that Sheldon's behavior is consistent with [[Asperger syndrome]].{{cite web|last=Soraya|first=Lynne|title=Sheldony or Aspergery?: The Big Bang Theory|url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/aspergers-diary/200904/sheldony-or-aspergery-the-big-bang-theory|work=Asperger's Diary (Author's Note (08/16/2009))|publisher=Psychology Today|accessdate=April 16, 2012}} The writers have stated that they did not use Asperger syndrome as a basis for the character, but instead thought of his actions as "Sheldony".{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Paul|title=Must-Geek TV: Is the world ready for an Asperger's sitcom?|work=Slate|publisher=www.slate.com|date=February 6, 2009|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2210635/pagenum/all/#p2|accessdate=April 14, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210061649/http://www.slate.com/id/2210635/pagenum/all/|archivedate=February 10, 2009}} Series co-creator Bill Prady stated: "We write the character as the character. A lot of people see various things in him and make the connections. Our feeling is that Sheldon's mother never got a diagnosis, so we don't have one." Prady also told Alan Sepinwall of the New Jersey ''[[Star-Ledger]]'' that while Sheldon shares traits with people with Asperger's, he was uncomfortable labeling Sheldon as having Asperger's.{{cite web|last=Sepinwall|first=Alan|title=Does Sheldon from 'Big Bang Theory' have Asperger's?|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/tv/index.ssf/2009/08/reader_mail_does_sheldon_from.html|publisher=The Star-Ledger|date=August 13, 2009|accessdate=July 27, 2012}} In an interview, Jim Parsons noted the writers' response, but added that, in his opinion, Sheldon "couldn't display ''more'' traits" of Asperger's.{{cite news|last=Lyford|first=Kathy|title='Big Bang Theory': Jim Parsons – 'Everybody has a little Sheldon in them'|work=Season Pass|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=November 13, 2008|url=http://weblogs.variety.com/season_pass/2008/11/big-bang-theory.html|accessdate=April 14, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120722163909/http://weblogs.variety.com/season_pass/2008/11/big-bang-theory.html|archivedate=July 22, 2012|df=mdy-all}} Specific video is [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tOH2XD7KEeY Jim Parsons interview, part 5]. Question is from 03:18–3:31. Answer is from 4:36–6:00. Specific quote is from 5:15–5:20. Parsons, who plays Sheldon, has read [[John Elder Robison]]'s memoir ''[[Look Me in the Eye]]'' about his life with Asperger syndrome, and said that: "A majority of what I read in that book touched on aspects of Sheldon." He also stated that "the way his brain works, it's so focused on the intellectual topics at hand that thinking he's autistic is an easy leap for people watching the show to make".{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/jim-parsons,27415/|title=Jim Parsons|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=May 1, 2009|accessdate=January 15, 2010}} When another actor on the series, [[Mayim Bialik]], who plays Amy and has a Ph.D. in Neuroscience, was interviewed by [[Neil deGrasse Tyson]] on ''[[StarTalk (podcast)|StarTalk]]'', she said of the theory that Sheldon has Asperger's: "All of our characters are in theory on the neuropsychiatric spectrum, I would say. Sheldon often gets talked about in terms of Asperger’s or OCD. He has a thing with germs, he has a thing with numbers, he’s got a lot of that precision that we see in OCD. There’s a lot of interesting features to all of our characters that make them technically unconventional socially.... And what we’re trying to show with our show is that this is a group of people who likely were teased, mocked, told that they will never be appreciated or loved, and we have a group of people who have successful careers, active social lives (that involve things like Dungeons and Dragons and video games), but they also have relationships, and that’s a fulfilling and satisfying life.”{{cite news|last=Gill|first=Jim|title='Is Sheldon autistic? The Big Bang Theory actress Mayim Bialik gives this brilliant response'|publisher=Immediate Media Company|date=15 June 2015|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-06-15/is-sheldon-autistic-the-big-bang-theory-actress-mayim-bialik-gives-this-brilliant-response/|accessdate=January 12, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|25em}} {{Portal bar|Fictional characters|Comedy|Television|Physics}} {{The Big Bang Theory}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cooper, Sheldon}} [[Category:Fictional characters from Texas]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Pasadena, California]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2007]] [[Category:Fictional child prodigies]] [[Category:Atheism in television]] [[Category:Fictional theoretical physicists]] [[Category:Fictional atheists and agnostics]] [[Category:Fictional twins]] [[Category:The Big Bang Theory characters]] [[Category:Fictional people with eidetic memory]] [[Category:Fictional characters who became a protagonist in a spin-off]] [[Category:Child characters in television]] [[Category:Male characters in television]] [[Category:Narcissism in fiction]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2018}}
'''Shigemi Inaga''' (稲賀 繁美 1957 in [[Hiroshima]]) is a Japanese scholar,<ref name="pq">{{cite web |title=Full-time Faculty - INAGA Shigemi |url=http://research.nichibun.ac.jp/en/researcher/staff/s066/index.html |website=International Research Center for Japanese Studies |publisher=International Research Center for Japanese Studies |accessdate=28 June 2018}}</ref> in [[comparative literature]], culture, history of cultural exchange.
==Education== Inaga studied for a [[Master of Arts]] in [[comparative literature]] and [[19th-century French art]] history at [[University of Tokyo]] before being promoted in 1988 to [[Doctor of Philosophy]] (博士) (hakushi) at the [[Paris Diderot University]].<ref name="cinam">{{cite web |title=Shigemi Inaga |url=http://cimam.org/shigemi-inaga/ |website=International Committee for Museums and Collections of Modern Art |publisher=CINAM 2018 |accessdate=27 July 2018}}</ref>
==Career== From 1988 to 1990 Inaga was employed as an assistant in the Department of Liberal Arts. He then promoted to Associate professor at [[Mie University]], a position he held from 1990 to 1997. In 1997, Inaga was appointed to [[International Research Center for Japanese Studies]] and was promoted to full professor in 2004.<ref name="cinam"/> In 2006 to 2007 he was appointed visiting scholar at the [[John W. Kluge Center]] in the [[Library of Congress]], [[Washington, D.C.]]. Between 2013 to 2015, Inaga was appointed to [[Dean (education)|Dean]] of the School of Cultural and Social Studies at the [[Graduate University for Advanced Studies (Japan)]]. Between 2016 and 2018 Inaga was the Deputy Director-General, [[International Research Center for Japanese Studies]].<ref name="pq"/>
==Bibliography== ===As author===
* ''Modernity of Japanese Art History and its Exterior'' (Nihon Bijutsu no Kindai to sono Gaibu), Tokyo: NHK Publishing * I''n Search of haptic Plasticity: Soul Touching each Other, Forms Interwoven'' (Sesshoku zoukeiron, Fureau Tamashii, Tsumugareru Katachi), Nagoya, The University of Nagoya Press * ''Images on the Edge: A Historical Survey of East-Asian Trans-Cultural Modernities'' (kaiga no Rinkai : Kindai Higashi Azia Bijutushi no Shikkoku to Meiun), Nagoya, The University of Nagoya Press * ''L’Orient de la peinture : de l’Orientalisme au Japonisme'' (Kaiga no Tôhô, Orientarizumu kara Jyaponisumu he) Nagoya, The University of Nagoya Press * ''Le Crépuscule de la peinture; la lutte posthume d’Édouard Manet'' (Kaiga no Tasogare : Edowâdo Mane Botsugo no Tôsô), Nagoya, The University of Nagoya Press
===As editor===
* ''Pirate's View of the World History, A Reversed Perception of the Order of Things'' (Kaizoku-Shikan kara mita Sekaishi no Sai-Kôchiku), Kyoto: Shibunkaku Shuppan Ltd. * ''Vocabulaire de la spatialité japonaise'' (Nihon no seikatsu kūkan), coédité avec Philippe Bonnin et Nishida Masatsugu (dir.), Paris, CNRS Éditions * ''Oriental Consciousness between Reverie and Reality 1887-1953'' (Tôyô-Ishiki, Musô to Genjitsu no Aida, 19887-1953)'','' Kyoto, Minerva Publishing Co. Ltd. * ''A Not-yet ending “Moderninty”: Yagi Kazuo and the Objet-Cuit'' (Owarikirenai “Kindai”-Yagi Kazuo to Obuje-yaki) Co-edited with Hida Toyorô, Tokyo, Bigaku Shuppan * ''Books on Ukiyoe and Japanese Arts in English by Yone Noguchi,'' Tokyo, Edition Synapse (in 3 volumes) * ''Traditional Japanese Arts & Crafts; A Reconsideration from Inside and Outside Kyoto'' (Dentô Kôgei Saikô, Kyô no Uchi-soto), Kyoto, Shibunkaku Shuppan Ltd. * ''Toward an Ethics in Inter-Cultural Understanding'' (Ibunka Rikai no Rinri ni Mukete), Nagoya, The University of Nagoya Press
===As proceedings editor===
* ''A Pirate's View of World History--A Reversed Perception of the Order of Things From a Global Perspective.'' The 50th International Research Symposium：IRCJS * ''Pour un Vocabulaire de la Spatialité Japonaise.'' The 43rd International Research Symposium (edited with Philippe Bonnin and Nishida Masatsugu), IRCJS * ''Questioning Oriental Aesthetics and Thinking: Conflicting Visions of “Asia” under the Colonial Empires.'' The 38th International Research Symposium, IRCJS * ''Artistic Vagabondage and New Utopian Projects: Transnational Poïetic Experience in East-Asian Modernity (1905-1960)'' :Selected Papers from the XIXth Congress of the International Comparative Literature Association, Seoul, 2010, ''Expanding the Frontiers of Comparative Literature'', Kyoto, IRCJS, Uno Printing Ltd. . * ''Traditional Japanese Arts and Crafts in the 21st Century -Reconsidering the Future from an International Perspective'' (edited with Patricia Fister), International Research Symposium Proceedings 27: IRCJS * C''rossing Cultural Borders: Toward an Ethics of Intercultural Communication -Beyond Reciprocal Anthropology'' (edited with Kenneth L. Richard), International Research Symposium Proceedings 14, IRCJS
===As periodicals guest editor===
* ''Depiction and Description: Morphology of Modern Visuality and Marketplace in Transition—Methodological Reflections, Art History Forum,'' special issue, Vol.20. * ''The making of Art History, History of Architecture and Archaeology ib Modernizing East-Asia, Nihon-Kenkyû, Bulletin of the International Research Center for Japanese Studies'', No.26.
===As translator=== * Pierre Bourdieu, ''Ce que parler veut dire, économie des échanges lingusitiques'' (en japonais), as ''Hanasu to iukoto, Gengoteki Kôkan no Ekonomi'', Tokyo, Fujiwara Shoten Ltd. * Rachel Burns, ''Edgar Degas'' (into Japanese), as ''Doga,'' Tokyo, Nikkei Pocket Gallery
==Awards==
* [[Watsuji Tetsuro Culture Award]] 2000 * [[Suntory Prize]] for Social Sciences and Humanities 1998 * [[Ringa Art Incentive Award]] 1998 * Special Award, [[Shibusawa-Claudel Prize]] 1997 * Japonaiserie Study Society Award 1980
== Academic society memberships ==
* [[Association for Asian Studies]] * [[European Association for Japanese Studies]] * [[International Comparative Literature Association]] * Word and Image, Sociologie de l'art * Japonisme Research Society * Société franco-Japonaise d'art et d'archéologie * Japan Comparative Literature Association * Meiji Art Association * Japan Art History Society
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.nichibun.ac.jp/~aurora/inaga/ Shigemi Inaga Academic Research Laboratory]
